author: By Jason Bailey
title: Watch These 13 Movies Before They Leave Netflix in March
description: It’s awards season, and a bunch of great Oscar-winning and -nominated films are leaving this month. Check them out while you can.
content: The Academy Awards arrive at the end of March, and the titles leaving Netflix in the United States this month are steeped in Oscar glory, including multiple nominees and winners for best picture, actor, actress and more. They also include hit comedies, erotic thrillers and family favorites. Queue up these 13 movies before they’re gone. (Dates reflect the final day a title is available.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: With Jeter and the Marlins, an Awkward Marriage Ends in Divorce
description: A winner on the field, Derek Jeter resigned as chief executive of the struggling Marlins, saying “the vision for the future of the franchise is different than the one I signed up to lead.”
content: Derek Jeter crossed the threshold into baseball immortality last September with induction into the Hall of Fame. Most people stop running at the finish line, but not Jeter. Few had ever taken the stage while also holding a demanding executive position, putting off a cushy retirement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: How Immigration Politics Drives Some Hispanic Voters to the G.O.P. in Texas
description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s brand of populism has been widely viewed as an appeal to white voters. But similar grievances have resonated in the Rio Grande Valley in a profound way.
content: BROWNSVILLE, Texas — Mayra Flores, the daughter of Mexican immigrants, has done much of her campaigning in South Texas in Spanish. She has heard one phrase repeatedly from voters as she and other candidates try to become the first Republicans to represent the Rio Grande Valley in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: For Older Americans, Some Positive Health News
description: Three recent developments — incremental and undramatic but encouraging — are likely to improve the lives and health of seniors.
content: The Covid pandemic has presented older Americans with plenty of grim news, from staffing shortages in long-term care and hospices to the punishing effects of loneliness and isolation. But there have been encouraging developments too — the kind of incremental progress that can take years to achieve, as lawsuits wend their way through courts, bills die in state legislatures and rise again, and the pandemic complicates everything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: Threats Emerge in Germany as Far Right and Pandemic Protesters Merge
description: In the former Communist East, security officials worry that a long-running movement against Covid restrictions is becoming an incubator of political violence.
content: DRESDEN, Germany — First vaccine opponents attacked the police. Then a group of them chatted online about killing the governor. And one day an angry crowd beating drums and carrying torches showed up outside the house of the health minister of the eastern state of Saxony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stirn
title: In Search of Panama’s Elusive Spider Monkeys
description: Environmental initiatives in the Azuero Peninsula offer hope for the future of a critically endangered subspecies.
content: For a brief moment, as hundreds of blue morpho butterflies floated gracefully around us, the green hues of the tropical forest were transformed into a neon blue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Woods and Delphine Danhier
title: Colorful Knits That Harness the Boundless Energy of Spring
description: The season’s sweaters favor loud patterns and styles — from mélange to patchwork and stripes — and have texture to spare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘After Yang’ and the State of the Union
description: Colin Farrell, Jodie Turner-Smith and Justin H. Min star in a new sci-fi movie on Showtime. And President Biden delivers a State of the Union address.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Feb. 28-March 6. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ESPN Rebrands Black-Focused Undefeated Site as Andscape
description: The operation will continue to cover the intersection of race, sports and culture but will expand into publishing, live events, music, TV and film.
content: “You may encounter many defeats, but you must not be defeated.” That quote, from Maya Angelou, inspired The Undefeated, an ESPN media platform that, from its start in 2016, has helped shape the national conversation by exploring the intersection of race, sports and culture from a Black point of view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Kyrie Irving still won’t be able to play in Brooklyn if the mayor lifts some Covid restrictions next week.
description: Barclays Center would remain under a private-sector vaccine mandate that took effect in December.
content: Kyrie Irving, the Nets’ star guard, will still be ineligible to play in home games at Barclays Center in Brooklyn if New York City lifts its vaccine mandate for restaurants, gyms and most indoor spaces, as Mayor Eric Adams said Sunday he intended to do by March 7 if Covid-19 cases remain low.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Russian Artists Speak Out Against War, but Fear Reprisals
description: Two Russian artists have pulled out of the Venice Biennale and thousands are signing antiwar petitions.
content: The young Russian artists Kirill Savchenkov and Alexandra Sukhareva were set to represent Russia in April at the Venice Biennale, the art-world jamboree that can turn little-known artists into global stars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Min Jin Lee
title: ‘Eyesight Compromised. Could Go Blind.’
description: In “The Beauty of Dusk,” Frank Bruni grapples with the effects of a stroke and finds solace — and wisdom — in talking to people who have suffered similar losses.
content: One October morning in 2017, the writer Frank Bruni woke up unable to see clearly. During the night, he had suffered a stroke, and the drop in blood pressure damaged an optic nerve, resulting in blindness in his right eye. After a series of doctors’ visits, Bruni learned that he had non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy, known by its acronym, NAION. While undergoing an experimental drug trial involving many needles, Bruni discovered that his partner, Tom, was unfaithful. Then Bruni’s father, the pillar in his life, developed dementia. Life keeps knocking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Volvo Cars halts sales to Russia, citing Ukraine sanctions and ‘potential risks.’
description: The Swedish carmaker’s move is a sign of how businesses may decide the hazards of doing business in Russia outweigh the risks.
content: Volvo Cars said on Monday that it would stop selling vehicles in Russia because of sanctions imposed by the United States and European Union, and because doing business there had become too risky after the invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Javen Fortner
title: The U.S. Has a Violence Problem, and It’s Up to Democrats to Solve It
description: A party at war with itself can provide neither greater peace nor sustainable reform.
content: We have a violence problem. This fact can no longer be ignored. Homicides increased more than 5 percent in 27 major American cities in 2021 over 2020, according to one study. Last year, at least 12 of those cities broke annual homicide records. Murders in New York City rose by 4 percent and in Chicago by 3 percent, following huge increases (45 percent and 55 percent, respectively) in 2020. In Los Angeles, homicides rose by 12 percent in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Feb. 28, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Feb. 28, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: Dr. Bronner’s, the Soap Company, Dips Into Psychedelics
description: Under the leadership of the founder’s grandsons, the company has become a big financial backer of efforts to loosen government restrictions on illegal drugs.
content: VISTA, Calif. — Dr. Bronner’s, the liquid soap company best known for its teeny-font labels preaching brotherly love and world peace, would like you to consider the benefits of mind-altering drugs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Questions Continue About Homeless Shelter Operators
description: New York City took a hands-off approach to overseeing the operators even as it acknowledged corruption.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at continuing problems with operators of homeless shelters. We’ll also find out about a personal project that two actors began during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: After a Fumbled Start, Russian Forces Hit Harder in Ukraine
description: After days of miscalculation about Ukraine’s resolve to fight, Russian forces are turning toward an old pattern of opening fire on cities and mounting sieges.
content: BRUSSELS — When Russia launched its invasion of Ukraine with nearly 200,000 troops, many observers — and seemingly President Vladimir V. Putin himself — expected that the force would roll right in and the fighting would be over quickly. Instead, after five days of war, what appears to be unfolding is a Russian miscalculation about tactics and about how hard the Ukrainians would fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: A Barrage of Rockets Hits Kharkiv
description: Russian forces escalate their attacks.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: He’s Sorry, She’s Sorry, Everybody Is Sorry. Does It Matter?
description: Joe Rogan. Whoopi Goldberg. Glenn Youngkin. We are swimming in a sea of public contrition, where everyone’s sorry and at the same time, no one is sorry enough.
content: When the writers Marjorie Ingall and Susan McCarthy started the blog SorryWatch a decade ago, they were told, repeatedly, that “apologies were having a moment.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: They Are Fans of ‘Euphoria,’ but Not of Its Creator, Sam Levinson
description: The season finale of “Euphoria” demonstrated once again that even its most impassioned fans have decidedly mixed feelings about its writer and director.
content: When the finale of the second season of “Euphoria” aired Sunday evening on HBO, the social media conversation about the gritty teen drama revolved around one character’s death, a battle royale between two other characters and the arc of Rue, the troubled teen played by Zendaya.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong
title: Retail Theft Rises, and N.Y.C. Small Business Owners Are Paying the Price
description: In New York City, neighborhood stores are struggling to confront the crimes that have cascaded from the disruptions of the pandemic.
content: Someone shattered the front door overnight and ripped out the cash drawer. The new security gates cost $2,300. The streets became quieter after four neighboring businesses closed permanently during the pandemic, emboldening shoplifters. Two security guards quit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Zelensky, in a passionate speech, urges the E.U. to admit Ukraine immediately.
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged the European Union on Monday to grant his country immediate accession to the bloc in response to Russia’s invasion.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged the European Union on Monday to grant his country immediate accession to the bloc in response to Russia’s invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
title: Putin Declares a Nuclear Alert, and Biden Seeks De-escalation
description: When the Russian leader ordered his nuclear forces into “special combat readiness,” the U.S. could have gone on high alert. Instead, the administration tried not to inflame him.
content: WASHINGTON — When Vladimir V. Putin declared Sunday that he was putting his nuclear forces into “special combat readiness” — a heightened alert status reminiscent of some of the most dangerous moments of the Cold War — President Biden and his aides had a choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.5 Million Homes in California
description: A Craftsman house in Upland, a Colonial Revival home in Alameda and a two-bedroom condominium in Beverly Hills.
content: Upland, a city in San Bernardino County with around 75,000 residents, sits at the base of the San Gabriel Mountains. This house was built in 1906 by Herman Eymann, the owner of a local lumberyard and a company that sold homes through a catalog, and it has been well maintained by subsequent owners, inside and out: It not only retains its original interior woodwork, but the grounds include an oak tree planted by a member of the Eymann family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Stromae’s Music Delves Into Dark Topics. His Return Is Right on Time.
description: The Belgian singer-songwriter’s hits marry serious subject matter and dancey beats. His first album in nine years, “Multitude,” expands his spectrum of sounds.
content: Growing up in Belgium, Stromae was a big rap fan. “Hip-hop was like school when I was between the ages of 16 and 21,” he said earlier this month. “People like G. Dep, Black Rob and Notorious B.I.G. were my models.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Blakeman
title: Out of the Desert, a Rare Fruit Garden and a Lasting Legacy
description: Dr. Alois Falkenstein put decades of work into breeding and cultivating rare fruits in the Arizona desert, and created a community of like-minded gardeners.
content: MESA, Ariz. — Jane Falkenstein’s house looks like any other single-family home in the Salt River Valley of Arizona — beige stucco, gravel lawn, a two-car garage, a shaggy palm tree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Cook Up Shrimp Burgers, No Chopping Required
description: Del Pacifico’s wild-caught shrimp burgers come frozen and are quick to sear in a skillet.
content: Your lobster roll is usually served in a hot dog bun. Now you can put a burger bun to work with shrimp. Del Pacifico’s wild-caught shrimp burgers, made with chopped, sustainable and fair trade blue Mexican shrimp with only black pepper, garlic and olive oil added, are a mild-tasting, nicely textured candidate. The company says its shrimp are certified for sustainability by Fair Trade USA and Friend of the Sea. In addition, each lot can be traced through lot numbers on each package. They come frozen and are quick to sear in a cast-iron skillet or on the grill. Sauces and garnishes are chef’s choice: aioli, Thousand Island, salsa, ripe tomato, avocado, red onion, you name it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Sokol
title: In Miami, a Ukrainian Art Show Becomes Unintentionally Timely
description: A Kyiv couple stage a socially charged exhibition in South Florida as their Voloshyn Gallery back home becomes a bomb shelter.
content: The wife-and-husband gallerists Julia and Max Voloshyn had planned to return to Kyiv last week to open a new show at their space there. But with commercial air traffic halted as Russian troops invaded Ukraine, their stay in Miami — and the run of their pop-up exhibition there — was extended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gordon
title: Online Dating Can Kill You. Literally.
description: In Jane Pek’s debut novel, “The Verifiers,” an unlikely sleuth starts out researching digital Casanovas — and finds herself involved in a possible murder.
content: THE VERIFIERSBy Jane Pek
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: School Is Back in Person, but the Five-Day School Week Often Isn’t
description: We asked 148,000 parents how many days of school their children missed in January. A quarter said more than a week.
content: Last month, at the height of the Omicron wave, one quarter of U.S. schoolchildren missed more than a week of in-person learning, according to a national survey of 148,400 parents by The New York Times and the survey and data firm Dynata.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano and Sheera Frenkel
title: Ukraine War Tests the Power of Tech Giants
description: Google, Meta, Twitter, Telegram and others are levers in the conflict, caught between demands from Ukraine, Russia, the European Union and the U.S.
content: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has become a defining geopolitical moment for some of the world’s biggest tech companies, as their platforms have turned into major battlefields for a parallel information war and their data and services have become vital links in the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joey Roulette
title: Mission to Mars with Russia this year is now ‘very unlikely,’ European Space Agency says.
description: The ExoMars mission, postponed in 2020 because of the pandemic and technical issues, may miss its window to launch this year because of sanctions imposed against Russia over the invasion of Ukraine.
content: The planned launch in 2022 of a European space mission with Russia to land a robot on Mars is now “very unlikely,” the European Space Agency said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Russia’s nuclear forces on alert.
content: Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, further intensified the crisis in Ukraine by placing his nuclear forces on alert, threatening the West as it rallied behind Ukraine. President Biden chose to de-escalate by refusing to change America’s own alert status, portraying Putin as once again manufacturing a menace. Follow the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G Smith
title: More People Are Microdosing for Mental Health. But Does It Work?
description: Scientists are split over whether the benefits some microdosers experience are a placebo effect or something more.
content: Joseph started microdosing psychedelics five years ago to try to improve his mental health. “I was just kind of in this depression, in this rut,” he said. “I was unhappy and angry and agitated all the time, and it went against the way that I saw myself.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Top Estée Lauder Executive Forced Out for Racist Instagram Post
description: John Demsey, an executive vice president, was a powerful figure at the company, which has been scrutinized for its diversity efforts.
content: Estée Lauder said on Monday that it had asked John Demsey, a top executive at the beauty giant, to leave the company after he posted a meme containing a racial slur on his Instagram account.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Biden administration faces pressure to let Ukrainians stay in the U.S.
description: Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, has called on the administration to offer Temporary Protected Status to Ukrainians who are on short-term visas or have no documentation.
content: The Biden administration is facing mounting pressure from lawmakers and advocates to allow thousands of Ukrainians who are temporarily working or studying in the United States to remain, rather than force them to return to their war-torn country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Singapore’s Latest Ruling on Gay Sex Is ‘Cold Comfort,’ Activists Say
description: Plaintiffs had hoped the Court of Appeal would overturn the colonial-era law. Instead, the top court said it was not “an architect of social policy” and that any change was up to Parliament.
content: The Singapore Court of Appeal, the country’s top court, declined Monday to overturn a law criminalizing gay sex, ruling that three men who brought challenges did not have legal standing because the government has pledged not to enforce the colonial-era law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. escalates sanctions with a freeze on Russian central bank assets.
description: The action is likely to fuel rapid inflation in Russia as it wages war in Ukraine.
content: WASHINGTON — The Treasury Department on Monday moved to further cut off Russia from the global economy, announcing that it would immobilize Russian central bank assets that are held in the United States and impose sanctions on the Russian Direct Investment Fund, a sovereign wealth fund that is run by a close ally of President Vladimir V. Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Need an Irish Whiskey Primer? Trust the Dead Rabbit.
description: The new book “Paddy Drinks” serves as a reference and a guide to the Manhattan bar’s cocktail ethos.
content: After nearly a century in the shadows, Irish whiskey is rebounding toward its former dominance. It’s all explained by David Wondrich, a drinks scholar and writer, who details the trajectory and the evolution of Irish bars in the United States since the 17th century in his foreword to “Paddy Drinks: The World of Modern Irish Whiskey Cocktails.” The book, by most of the partners in the Dead Rabbit, an esteemed bar in Lower Manhattan, is an up-to-date treatise on the whiskey, defining its four styles: pot still, malt, grain and blended. There are details for about 50 labels, and the book serves as a technical primer on Irish whiskey cocktails and how to build them. Following recipes for six classics, there are scores of Dead Rabbit creations, most of which call for esoteric ingredients like tonka bean syrup, za’atar tincture and toasted fennel salt (recipes are provided). There are a few more pantry-friendly options, like the head bartender Jillian Vose’s deliciously bitter Broadway Junction and the Precision Pilot, which she said was one of the first drinks she created at the bar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Harvey Fierstein Sings the Song of Himself in ‘I Was Better Last Night’
description: The actor and writer recounts his life, from Bensonhurst upbringing to Broadway smashes, in a raw, funny and fabulous memoir.
content: The actor, writer and consummate New Yawker Harvey Fierstein is assuredly a man of many talents. Who knew needlework was one of them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Shell Quits Russia, Joining BP as Oil Giants Object to Attack on Ukraine
description: Shell said it would exit its investments in Russia, a day after BP said it would do the same. Now companies like TotalEnergies and Exxon will face questions.
content: Shell, Europe’s largest oil company, said on Monday that it would exit its joint ventures with Gazprom, the Russian natural gas giant. It is joining BP, which said on Sunday that it would sell its nearly 20 percent stake in Rosneft, the Russian state-controlled oil company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Uber distances itself from Yandex.Taxi, the Russian ride-sharing service.
description: Uber said it would try to ‘accelerate’ the planned sale of its shares in the Russian service.
content: Uber said Monday that it was trying to “accelerate” its divestment from the Russian internet company Yandex, which operates a ride-hailing service in Russia, in light of the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Oil prices climb as Ukraine crisis deepens.
description: A nuclear threat, and skepticism at potential talks.
content: Oil prices jumped on Monday, as President Vladimir V. Putin’s saber-rattling order to put his country’s nuclear forces on high alert overshadowed hopes for negotiations between Russia and Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Kandinsky Painting Returned to Jewish Heirs by Amsterdam Museum
description: Dutch officials, citing their “moral duty,” gave over the work which had been held by the Stedelijk Museum since 1940.
content: The City of Amsterdam on Monday handed over a painting by the Russian artist Wassily Kandinsky to heirs of a Jewish couple who had sold it as they tried to escape the Netherlands after the Nazi invasion during World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Dayen
title: Larry Summers Shares the Blame for Inflation
description: The Democratic economist is deeply implicated in building the system at the heart of our current predicament and setting up our economy for failure.
content: “Any honest Democrat will admit that we are now all Friedmanites,” Larry Summers wrote in The Times in 2006. Mr. Summers comes from a family of left-leaning economists who saw Milton Friedman as a “devil figure.” But as he moved into the upper echelons of the family profession, Mr. Summers came to have “great admiration” for the conservative thinker and his work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Considers Limiting E.P.A.’s Ability to Address Climate Change
description: Members of the court’s conservative majority voiced skepticism that Congress had authorized the agency to decide what they said were major political and economic questions.
content: WASHINGTON — Members of the Supreme Court’s conservative majority on Monday questioned the scope of the Environmental Protection Agency’s ability to regulate carbon emissions from power plants, suggesting that the justices could deal a sharp blow to the Biden administration’s efforts to address climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Tariq Panja
title: Russia Faces Global Sports Crackdown After Invasion of Ukraine
description: The International Olympic Committee recommended that Russian and Belarusian athletes be barred from competitions.
content: An article of faith in global sports — that athletes should not be punished for the actions of their governments — crumbled on Monday, when executives worldwide moved to banish Russians from competitions and deepen the country’s isolation for its invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins, Steven Erlanger and Michael Schwirtz
title: Russian Rocket Barrage Kills Civilians as First Talks Show No Progress
description: The deadly rocket assault on a residential area of Ukraine’s second-largest city signaled an escalation of Russian tactics, and overshadowed efforts at diplomacy.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — The first talks between Ukraine and Russia aimed at halting the Russian invasion were eclipsed Monday by a deadly Russian rocket assault on Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-largest city, that raised new alarms about how far the Kremlin was willing to go to subjugate its smaller neighbor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Invasion Brings Russia Global Repudiation With Cold War Echoes
description: From culture to commerce, sports to travel, the world is shunning Russia in myriad ways to protest President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: LONDON — In Switzerland, the Lucerne music festival canceled two symphony concerts featuring a Russian maestro. In Australia, the national swim team said it would boycott a world championship meet in Russia. At the Magic Mountain Ski Area in Vermont, a bartender poured bottles of Stolichnaya vodka down the drain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer, Raymond Zhong and Lisa Friedman
title: Time Is Running Out to Avert a Harrowing Future, Climate Panel Warns
description: The impacts of global warming are appearing faster than expected, according to a major new scientific report. It could soon become much harder to cope.
content: The dangers of climate change are mounting so rapidly that they could soon overwhelm the ability of both nature and humanity to adapt, creating a harrowing future in which floods, fires and famine displace millions, species disappear and the planet is irreversibly damaged, a major new scientific report has concluded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer and Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Markets are turbulent as sanctions start to isolate Russia’s economy.
description: Energy prices jumped and stocks on Wall Street fell. The New York Stock Exchange halted trading in shares of Russian companies.
content: Stocks on Wall Street fell on Monday and commodity prices rose as the war in Ukraine entered its fifth day and a widening array of sanctions aimed at punishing Russia for its invasion began to bite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: How to Lead New York Into the Next Phase of Covid-19
description: Relaxing restrictions now makes sense, but the mayor must also prepare the city for the next phase of the pandemic.
content: New York City, one of the nation’s first epicenters of the coronavirus pandemic, is on the cusp of stepping into the next hopeful chapter of this crisis, and Mayor Eric Adams is leading the way. On Sunday, Mr. Adams announced that he would eliminate school mask mandates and vaccine requirements for restaurants, gyms and movie theaters by next Monday, as long as case numbers remain low.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Isaac-Goizé
title: The Best-Kept Vintage Secret in Paris
description: For decades, Catherine B has been a fashion resource for celebrities and collectors alike.
content: PARIS — Not long after Rihanna wore a vintage pink Chanel puffer for her pregnancy announcement, another example of the very same coat appeared — at an auction in Paris, where it was sold for 2,500 euros ($2,830), beating its high estimate by 66 percent. Not that it came from Rihanna’s closet, though the actual owner has her own level of fame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: meticulous
description: This word has appeared in 240 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word meticulous has appeared in 240 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 22 in “A Time Capsule Beneath a Lee Statue Reveals More Mysteries” by Eduardo Medina:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Were These Doctors Treating Pain or Dealing Drugs?
description: The Supreme Court will hear from two convicted pill mill doctors in cases that could have significant implications for physicians’ latitude to prescribe addictive painkillers.
content: For years, Dr. Xiulu Ruan was one of the nation’s top prescribers of quick-release fentanyl drugs. The medicines were approved only for severe breakthrough pain in cancer patients, but Dr. Ruan dispensed them almost exclusively for more common ailments: neck aches, back and joint pain. According to the Department of Justice, he and his partner wrote almost 300,000 prescriptions for controlled substances from 2011 to 2015, filled through the doctors’ own pharmacy in Mobile, Ala. Dr. Ruan often signed prescriptions without seeing patients, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Sharon Otterman and Nicole Hong
title: New York City Is Rolling Back Pandemic Restrictions. Is It Too Soon?
description: Mayor Eric Adams plans to end certain mask and vaccine mandates in hopes of restoring a sense of normalcy. Some health experts think he should wait.
content: The day after announcing that he planned to end New York City’s mask mandate for public schools and a proof-of-vaccination requirement for indoor dining, gyms and entertainment venues, Mayor Eric Adams smiled broadly as he rang the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Maggie Gyllenhaal Wants to Tell the Transgressive Stories of Motherhood
description: The director of ‘The Lost Daughter’ thinks Hollywood has only scratched the surface of women’s storytelling.
content: Rewarding as it is, motherhood can be an uphill battle. In the pandemic, we heard this in the stories of mothers struggling to juggle child care and schooling with work and other responsibilities at home. But the pandemic simply lifted the curtain on an underrepresented reality for many parents. Actor, writer and director Maggie Gyllenhaal seeks to capture the messiness of motherhood in her new film “The Lost Daughter.” It’s an adaptation of the Elena Ferrante novel that explores the story of an “unnatural mother” named Leda, who finds parenting to be a “crushing responsibility.” Gyllenhaal imagined playing scenes of a mother ignoring her daughter’s cries or rejecting her injured child’s pleas for a kiss — things we’re taught “we’re not allowed to think or feel” — would be “radical” for a film, especially if women watched with their mothers, partners or children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacqueline Mroz
title: When an Ancestry Search Reveals Fertility Fraud
description: Starting in the 1960s, three physicians in Rochester, N.Y., began secretly using their own sperm to help women become pregnant.
content: Like millions of Americans, David Berry was curious about his genealogy. He wanted to learn more about his paternal grandfather, whose ancestry was British. But as he explored his father’s side of the family, he discovered something wholly unexpected: The man he thought was his father was not related to him at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: New York City’s Next Chapter
description: The new mayor is rolling back virus mandates.
content: Mayor Eric Adams said today that he was preparing to eliminate school mask mandates and indoor proof-of-vaccine requirements by March 7 if new coronavirus cases in the city remain low.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: The White House lifts its mask mandate for fully vaccinated people.
description: The move takes effect Tuesday, in time for President Biden’s State of the Union address.
content: The White House is relaxing its mask mandate in time for President Biden’s State of the Union address on Tuesday, according to a memo sent to staff on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: E.U. sees adequate winter energy, but seeks longer-term independence.
description: The organization’s energy commissioner said the Russian invasion of Ukraine had exposed vulnerabilities in European energy supplies.
content: Europe’s energy supply is sufficient to get through the winter, but the Russian invasion of Ukraine has exposed vulnerabilities that need to be addressed, the European Union's energy commissioner said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Here’s the latest news from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
description: As Ukraine’s second largest city reeled under a barrage of Russian rockets that left dozens of people dead, officials said, a Ukrainian delegation met counterparts from Russia on Monday in Belarus for talks that held little hope for an immediate end to the fighting that has sparked a nationwide resistance in Ukraine and left Russia’s economy increasingly isolated from the world.
content: As Ukraine’s second largest city reeled under a barrage of Russian rockets that left dozens of people dead, officials said, a Ukrainian delegation met counterparts from Russia on Monday in Belarus for talks that held little hope for an immediate end to the fighting that has sparked a nationwide resistance in Ukraine and left Russia’s economy increasingly isolated from the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Julia Harris
title: Shelter Operator Cited for Nepotism Still Gets Millions in City Funds
description: New York officials found misspending by African American Planning Commission, which runs homeless shelters, but public money continued to flow.
content: When New York City faced criticism last year for its lax oversight of homeless shelter contracts, officials pledged to root out nepotism and financial misconduct by those who might seek to cash in on the $2 billion system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What Questions Do You Have About Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine?
description: New York Times reporters will answer reader questions about the war, the world’s response and the effects of sanctions against Russia.
content: The U.N. General Assembly met Monday to to discuss the invasion of Ukraine, even as the country said dozens were killed in a Russian rocket attack in Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-largest city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Democratic Governors Look to Biden for a Political Reset
description: At a weekend fund-raising retreat, a group of governors worried about voters’ frustrations with Democrats. They hoped President Biden’s State of the Union speech would be a pivot point.
content: MANALAPAN, Fla. — Democratic governors and their allies are expressing deep anxiety about the political conditions facing their party as President Biden’s approval rating slumps in a year when three dozen governorships are on the line, including in some of the nation’s most important battleground states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Simon Johnson, Kaitlin Roberts, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Alexandra Leigh Young, Larissa Anderson, Lisa Chow, Lisa Tobin, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: The Battle for Kyiv
description: Reporting from the Ukrainian capital as the once vibrant, bustling city is turned into a war zone.
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and Raymond Zhong
title: Climate Change Is Harming the Planet Faster Than We Can Adapt, U.N. Warns
description: Countries aren’t doing nearly enough to protect against the disasters to come as the planet keeps heating up, a major new scientific report concludes.
content: The dangers of climate change are mounting so rapidly that they could soon overwhelm the ability of both nature and humanity to adapt unless greenhouse gas emissions are quickly reduced, according to a major new scientific report released on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: Here Comes the Full Amazonification of Whole Foods
description: A newly revamped store in Washington shows how thoroughly Amazon has woven itself into the grocery shopping experience.
content: “Would you like to sign in with your palm?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Edi Patterson on Tapping Into Her Id for ‘The Righteous Gemstones’
description: Ahead of the Season 2 finale, the actress, writer and producer talked about the joys of being Judy in this HBO comedy about a family of televangelists.
content: This interview contains spoilers for the Season 2 finale of “The Righteous Gemstones.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: ‘You Have to Be Delusional’: A Minor Leaguer’s Hard Road to the Bigs
description: While big leaguers fight with owners about labor issues, minor leaguers like Jack Kruger are getting ready for another season of long bus rides and longer odds.
content: Jack Kruger was about to start a season with yet another minor league baseball team, the Salt Lake Bees, a Class AAA team in Utah, when his cellphone rang.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Neil Diamond Sells Entire Catalog to Universal Music
description: The musician behind ubiquitous hits like “Sweet Caroline” sold his songwriting rights and recordings in another major deal.
content: Bob Dylan. Bruce Springsteen. Paul Simon. Neil Young. Stevie Nicks. All have sold their music catalogs over the last year and a half for huge sums, part of a broad transference of the ownership of a generation’s music from artists to corporations and investors. But is there any big game left?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo, Robert Chiarito, Joel Wolfram, Matt Berg and Eric Adelson
title: ‘Ukrainian People Don’t Give Up Hope’: U.S. Rallies Express Solidarity
description: At events in Washington, Chicago, Boston and other cities on Sunday, demonstrators expressed their love for the country, anger at Vladimir Putin and hope for peace.
content: Bearing blue and yellow Ukrainian flags, singing patriotic songs and shouting chants against Russia’s president, thousands of protesters gathered at rallies across the country on Sunday in a show of support for Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Graham Bowley
title: Treasured Paintings Burned in Russian Invasion, Ukrainian Officials Say
description: Roughly 25 works by the painter Maria Primachenko were destroyed at a museum in Ivankiv, Ukraine’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs said.
content: Roughly 25 paintings by the celebrated Ukrainian artist Maria Primachenko were burned as a result of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the country’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement posted to social media on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: After a Pandemic Pause, the Marshal Restarts Its Dinner Series
description: The Hell's Kitchen restaurant will offer a series of farm-to-table meals, paired with New York wines, for the first time since 2019.
content: At the Marshal, the chef Charlie Marshall’s 10-year-old restaurant in Hell’s Kitchen, only New York State wines and spirits distilled in the Northeast are poured, the electricity is wind powered and the kitchen is fueled with apple and cherry wood, not gas. Next month Mr. Marshall is offering a series of farm-to-table dinners, most with six-courses and dessert, each paired with six New York wines. He has been doing the dinners for years, usually in February, but this is the first time they have taken place since 2019. Smallholdings, a label of Lot 10 Vineyard on Skaneateles Lake, and McCall Wines from Cutchogue, N.Y., are two new wineries involved in the series. The dinners are planned for March 1, 2, 8, 9, 14 and 15 at 7:30 p.m., $95 plus tax and gratuities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Miliband
title: Ukraine Presents a Moral Crisis, Not Just a Military One
description: All possible outcomes involve sacrifice and suffering on a huge scale.
content: With Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the military balance of power in Europe is up for grabs. The moral balance is also at stake. The West needs to show that it can live up to its values — as well as defend itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Noma’s Fish Sauce Has No Fish at All
description: Noma Projects sells smoked mushroom garum, a vegan interpretation of a fermented fish sauce used for centuries.
content: The first product for home cooks from Noma Projects, a food lab that was opened last year by the influential Copenhagen restaurant, is now available. It is a vegan interpretation of garum, the fermented fish sauce that’s been used as a seasoning since Ancient Rome, which will be familiar to anyone that’s used fish and oyster sauces from Asia, English Worcestershire and Italian colatura. At Noma they’ve turned to koji and mushrooms instead of fermented fish to create their umami-rich smoked mushroom garum. It’s not as intensely salty as some other garum-adjacent products, and the aroma and flavor reveal subtle smoke and mushrooms. There are recipes on the website. I tried the smoked mushroom cream sauce, dividing the recipe in half to complete it with and without the smoked mushroom garum. With the garum it was subtly more complex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: On ‘Better Things,’ a Small Story Goes Out With a Big Bang
description: Pamela Adlon’s comedy of family and chaos takes a cosmic perspective in its final season.
content: Many TV creators will tell you that they love their characters, and I’m sure they mean it. But nobody shows you that love quite the way Pamela Adlon does.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Putin Is Spinning the Globe Faster and Faster
description: Can Biden slow it down?
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. In 2006, I wrote a column for The Wall Street Journal that began with the sentence “It’s time we start thinking of Vladimir Putin’s Russia as an enemy of the United States.” At the time, the criticism I got came from the left. But if I wrote the same column today, most of the flak would come from the right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Wales and Scotland move to relax some pandemic restrictions.
description: Various masking and vaccination rules will ease, though the approach is more gradual than England’s.
content: Wales and Scotland, which set their own public health policies within Britain, each said on Monday that they were relaxing some pandemic rules, though neither went quite as far as England did last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin and Meridith Kohut
title: The One Item They Had to Take When These 6 Afghans Fled
description: More than 120,000 people were airlifted out of Afghanistan last August, most with just a few hours to gather their belongings. Here are some of the keepsakes they chose.
content: If you were leaving home forever and had just a few hours to collect your thoughts and most precious belongings, items that would have to fit into a knapsack or purse, or just your pockets, what would you choose?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Freshen Up Your Cooking With Ingredients Straight From Jordan
description: A new collection of spices and condiments from Kamā, in Amman, Jordan, includes local variations on za’atar, tahini and chile paste.
content: Jordanian kitchens rely on mostly the same ingredients that define the food of other countries in the Levant. But there are some differences, displayed in a new collection of spices and condiments from Kamā, in Amman, Jordan. The company was founded by Jumana Jacir, a designer who employs local people to obtain components from nearby farms and create their products. The za’atar is a brighter green with a somewhat mintier flavor than most; the tahini (tahiniyeh) has a more fluid consistency, making it easier to drizzle and to use for dressings; and the shatta chile paste comes in both a forcefully spicy and red version, like harissa, and in a somewhat milder and denser green version seasoned with za’atar that can be nicely mellowed by mixing it with olive oil. Ground sumac and date molasses are two of the other products, all in jars with informative labeling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Pakistan Will Cut Energy Prices to Offset Rising Costs After Invasion
description: Critics said the move by Prime Minister Imran Khan was aimed at stemming increasing criticism of his handling of the economy and would provide only temporary relief.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan announced Monday that he was slashing fuel and electricity prices to help offset rising global energy prices because of the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: FIFA Suspends Russia, Ejecting It From World Cup Qualifying
description: The decision to bar Russian clubs and national teams came a day after FIFA was criticized for not going far enough to punish Russia for invading Ukraine.
content: World soccer’s global governing body suspended Russia and its teams from all competitions on Monday, ejecting the country from qualifying for the 2022 World Cup only weeks before it was to play for one of Europe’s final places in this year’s tournament in Qatar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: Nightlife Inflation: The Cost of Going Out Is Going Up
description: Surging prices are taking a toll on a night on the town. “I remember just going ‘yikes’ when signing off on a nearly $80 bill,” a bar patron said.
content: On a crowded Saturday night at Pieces, a gay bar in Greenwich Village, Gregory Keller and three friends claimed a spot on the floor shortly before the drag performer Jasmine Kennedie took the stage. One of Mr. Keller’s friends bought the first round, another got the second, and then it was his turn. After a few failed attempts at flagging down a bartender, he ordered four vodka sodas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: Switzerland says it will freeze Russian assets, setting aside a tradition of neutrality.
description: The decision came amid mounting public anger at Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: GENEVA — Switzerland, a favorite destination for Russian oligarchs and their money, announced on Monday that it would freeze Russian financial assets in the country, setting aside a deeply rooted tradition of neutrality to join the European Union and a growing number of nations seeking to penalize Russia for the invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen and Jeanna Smialek
title: The West’s Plan to Isolate Putin: Undermine the Ruble
description: Measures announced over the weekend aimed at restricting the Russian central bank’s ability to support the ruble appear to be having an immediate impact.
content: By targeting Russia’s central bank with sanctions, experts said, American and European leaders have taken aim at what could be one of President Vladimir V. Putin’s greatest weaknesses: the country’s currency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Fighting Rages On
description: Sanctions hit Russia, crushing the ruble.
content: Delegations from Ukraine and Russia met in Belarus for hours of talks on Monday while Ukrainian officials accused Russians of bombing a residential area in Kharkiv and killing dozens. Follow our live updates, maps of the war and timeline of the crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Lucid Motors Will Produce Fewer Cars Than Expected
description: The electric car start-up cited supply chain problems.
content: Lucid Motors, a fledgling maker of electric cars, on Monday significantly scaled back its production goals for the year, citing supply chain problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Petersen
title: Have We Reached Peak Plant Milk? Not Even Close.
description: There is already a vast array of dairy alternatives, but experts say the flow of new offerings won’t slow down anytime soon.
content: It is a bountiful time for plant-based milks, with new varieties of nut, seed, grain, legume and now vegetable milks showing up on store shelves every year. Now comes potato milk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: 5 Takeaways From the U.N. Report on Climate Hazards
description: Global warming is affecting every part of the planet. Humans should have started preparing yesterday.
content: A body of experts convened by the United Nations has put out its most comprehensive look to date at how climate change is affecting our homes, health, livelihoods and infrastructure, as well as the natural systems upon which they all depend.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Armed or Not, Villagers Rush to Join Fight
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 28, 2022.
content: “The Russian leadership does not understand that it is at war not only with the armed forces of Ukraine, but with the entire Ukrainian people.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Brooklyn Academy of Music Plans a Global Season
description: The company’s spring offerings include the British choreographer Akram Khan’s “Giselle” and the Australian comedian Hannah Gadsby.
content: After focusing its most recent season on the artists of New York City, the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Monday announced a spring season filled with global offerings, including the New York premiere of the British choreographer Akram Khan’s “Giselle,” a series of shows by the Australian comedian Hannah Gadsby and a production of “Cyrano de Bergerac,” starring James McAvoy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: Toyota stops production in Japan after a cyberattack at a supplier.
description: A supplier to the automaker shut down its computer network in response to a hack.
content: TOKYO — Toyota, the world’s largest automaker, said on Tuesday that it would restart production in Japan after a cyberattack at a major supplier had forced the company to shut down its domestic production.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Sergey Ponomarev
title: As Sanctions Batter Economy, Russians Face the Anxieties of a Costly War
description: The ruble plunged, the stock market was shuttered and foreign investors shed holdings in Russian companies, deepening the concern among citizens who had become accustomed to the perks of globalization.
content: MOSCOW — For two decades under President Vladimir V. Putin, Russians reaped the bounties of capitalism and globalization: cheap flights, affordable mortgages, a plethora of imported gadgets and cars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Deadline Day Arrives as M.L.B. and Players Continue Negotiations
description: The league created urgency by stating any deal made after Monday would result in canceling some regular-season games.
content: JUPITER, Fla. — On Monday, minutes before 10 a.m., members of the negotiating team from the Major League Baseball players’ union made their daily walk from the parking lot of Roger Dean Stadium into their meeting room. Among the group: the veteran pitchers Andrew Miller and Max Scherzer, both top union representatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: An American-Forged Knife With Japanese Influences
description: Steelport Knife Co.’s new 6-inch chef model borrows aspects of a santoku.
content: Steelport Knife Company in Portland, Ore., a maker of American-forged carbon steel cutlery that started selling its 8-inch chef knife last year, has now introduced a less common 6-inch version. The shorter blade is slightly more curved at the tip and the shape borrows aspects of a Japanese santoku, so it’s wider than a Western chef knife, a useful feature. Eytan Zias and Ron Khormaei, who founded the company in 2020, said they “do not make any shapes which are classically French, Japanese or German, but rather design the knives in a practical way that makes sense to us and are most effective for the user.” They also point out that the United States does not have the defined traditions of other countries known for cutlery, so it’s easier to innovate. The knife sharpens easily, has a dark patina, a deep bolster and a beautiful if somewhat heavy handle of Oregon big leaf maple burl. It has heirloom written all over it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Katie Glueck
title: Cuomo Portrays Himself as a Victim in a Six-Figure TV Ad Blitz
description: Andrew Cuomo’s still-active campaign spent $369,000 to recast the sexual harassment case against him, pushing a narrative that he was driven out of office by “political attacks.”
content: Cut off from power, longtime friends and a political platform, former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has struggled for months to salvage a reputation that was all but destroyed when he resigned amid a slew of sexual harassment allegations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Season 6, Episode 6 Recap: I’ll Be Watching You
description: Prince takes a hit, and Taylor makes a hit job. The gamesmanship is getting expensive, in more ways than one.
content: There are few things on television I enjoy more than a good “Billions” fake-out. The sine qua non comes from the stellar Season 2 episode “Golden Frog Time,” in which a Chuck Rhoades who at first appears to be sobbing is actually laughing hysterically because his plan to undermine his enemy Bobby Axelrod worked like a charm. (At the expense of his best friend and his father, but still!)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Metropolitan Opera Says It Will Cut Ties With Pro-Putin Artists
description: The decision comes as arts institutions seek to distance themselves from some Russian performers amid the invasion of Ukraine.
content: The Metropolitan Opera said on Sunday that it would no longer engage with performers or other institutions that have voiced support for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, becoming the latest cultural organization to seek to distance itself from some Russian artists amid Mr. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Katie Rogers
title: 10 Consequential Days: How Biden Navigated War, Covid and the Supreme Court
description: The dizzying events of the past week have pushed to the sidelines the congressional squabbling over President Biden’s domestic agenda, and are already redefining the arc of his presidency.
content: WASHINGTON — Ron Klain, the White House chief of staff, gave a pep talk early on Feb. 18 at the daily gathering of the president’s most senior aides: The next 10 days, he said, will be the most consequential of the Biden presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: Speculators Win Big With Bets on Young Artists
description: When demand outstrips supply, there is huge money to be made by “flipping”— the practice of buying low from the artist’s gallery and reselling high at auction.
content: LONDON — Three years ago, her large paintings were selling at a little-known gallery for about $40,000 each. In 2021, one of them was resold at a Sotheby’s auction for a record $3.1 million. Another hangs in the Downing Street home of Britain’s finance minister, Rishi Sunak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli and Noah Weiland
title: Pfizer Shot Is Far Less Effective in 5- to 11-Year-Olds Than in Older Kids, New Data Show
description: While protection against hospitalization is still strong, the vaccine offered almost no protection against infection, even just a month after full vaccination.
content: The coronavirus vaccine made by Pfizer-BioNTech is much less effective in preventing infection in children ages 5 to 11 years than in older adolescents or adults, according to a large new set of data collected by health officials in New York State — a finding that has deep ramifications for these children and their parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘The Batman’ and Matt Reeves: Emerging From the Shadow of Other Caped Crusaders
description: Amid concurrent versions of the crime-fighter, this director aimed for something personal that would also serve a studio’s needs. The result is a foreboding vision.
content: Central to the mythology of Batman is the idea of the secret identity: Beneath his fearsome mask, he is really Bruce Wayne, the billionaire scion of grimy Gotham City, and beneath that, he is still the traumatized child who saw his parents murdered in front of him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wudan Yan
title: Researchers See ‘Future of an Entire Species’ in Ultrasound Technique
description: To bring abalone back from the edge of extinction, scientists need to find improved ways of coaxing the snails into reproducing.
content: Kristin Aquilino, a scientist at the University of California, Davis, knows that expectations are just disappointments in disguise. Over the last decade, she has led the school’s white abalone captive breeding program, which aims to bring the marine mollusk back from the brink of extinction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Daniil Medvedev Intrudes on the Big Four’s No. 1 Perch
description: After nearly two decades of four men trading places at tennis’s top slot, Russia’s Medvedev put an end to their reign on Monday.
content: Daniil Medvedev was 7 years old and living with his family in Moscow when Roger Federer rose to No. 1 in the ATP rankings on Feb. 2, 2004.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: The mask mandate in the Capitol is being lifted in time for the State of the Union.
description: This year’s address from the president, unlike last year’s, is open to all members of Congress.
content: The House of Representatives is lifting the House floor mask mandate in time for President Biden’s State of the Union address on Tuesday, ending a requirement that had allowed some Republicans to express their defiance, but at a personal cost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Initial talks between Russia and Ukraine yield no resolution.
description: Russia’s delegation leader said the next meeting would take place once more along the Ukraine-Belarus border in the “coming days.”
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Initial talks between Russia and Ukraine concluded without result on Monday evening, with both delegations returning from the site of the negotiations in Belarus to their capitals for consultations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How Do You Feel About Lifting School Mask Mandates?
description: We’re looking for thoughts from parents, students and educators.
content: School mask mandates are a hot topic. Some public health experts and parent activists say that the mandates can hurt children academically and socially. On the other hand, masks are an effective tool in preventing the spread of the coronavirus, and they can help keep vulnerable students safer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: European Sanctions Could Strand Leased Planes in Russia
description: European companies that have leased hundreds of planes to Russian airlines must now find a way to fly them out.
content: BERLIN — Western sanctions meant to punish President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for invading Ukraine may have also dealt a big blow to European companies that leased commercial aircraft to Russian airlines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Russeth
title: Chris Burden’s Impossible Artworks
description: A new book reveals the dozens of planned pieces that the artist, known for his extreme performances and wry installations, left unrealized.
content: Chris Burden’s death in 2015, at only 69, ended one of the most protean and captivating art careers of the past half-century. In the early 1970s, he created now-legendary works using his own body by having a friend shoot him in the arm at close range with a rifle (1971’s harrowing “Shoot”), or slithering across broken glass, nearly naked, hands behind his back (“Through the Night Softly,” from 1973). In later years, he focused his attention on whimsical, almost impossibly intricate installations, like a 65-foot-tall tower constructed out of replica Erector Set parts at New York’s Rockefeller Center (2008’s “What My Dad Gave Me”) and a cluster of 202 vintage street lamps in front of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art (“Urban Light,” also from 2008). Along the way, he built elaborate model bridges, dug trenches to expose a museum’s foundation and constructed a sculpture from borrowed gold bricks, always intent on examining — with both a gimlet eye and childlike wonder — power relations, technology and the systems that allow society to function.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Classroom Disruptions
description: We look at the surprising number of recent classroom shutdowns in the U.S. And the latest from Ukraine.
content: The debate over Covid-19 school closures can sometimes seem to be settled. There is now a consensus that children learned much less than usual — and that their mental health suffered — when schools were shut for months in 2020 and 2021. This consensus helps explain why very few school districts fully closed during the Omicron surge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What to Know About California’s Mask Rules
description: Officials are expected to announce a plan on Monday for relaxing the state’s classroom mask mandate.
content: With the Omicron variant in retreat across much of the country, federal officials on Friday inched toward a new pandemic normal by easing their guidelines for staying safe from the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The Meaning of Lent to This Unchurched Christian
description: Perfection isn’t possible. That’s OK.
content: NASHVILLE — On Wednesday, in Catholic parishes across the world, a priest will dip his thumb into a pot of ashes — the burned remains of blessed palms from last year’s Palm Sunday Mass — and smudge the sign of the cross on each congregant’s forehead. Performing this ancient ritual, he will murmur, “Remember that you are dust, and to dust you shall return.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘The Hidden Image Descriptions Making the Internet Accessible’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about alt text, image descriptions that help people who have low vision or are blind to use the internet. Then, they will practice using the feature.
content: Featured article: “The Hidden Image Descriptions Making the Internet Accessible” by Meg Miller and Ilaria Parogni
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: How Economic Warfare Is Battering Russia
description: “Completely unprecedented” financial sanctions against Russia are taking a global toll.
content: As the Russian military meets stiff resistance on the ground in Ukraine, the U.S. and its allies are aggressively escalating financial sanctions. The effects on the Russian economy could be devastating, and the global reverberations of the punishments, unheard-of in severity and scope for an economy of Russia’s size and interconnectedness, are destabilizing, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court to Hear Challenge to Law on Adopting Native American Children
description: The Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 gives preference to adoption solutions that would keep Native children within the tribal community.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to hear a challenge to the constitutionality of the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978, which makes it hard to remove Native American children from their parents, their tribes and their heritage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Sharrett
title: In a Tiny Appalachian Village, a Beloved Festival Returns
description: The Fasnacht celebration in Helvetia, W.Va., draws revelers who soak in the Swiss culture — and burn Old Man Winter in effigy.
content: HELVETIA, W.Va. — As the sun set below the ridgelines of the Appalachian Mountains on Saturday evening, revelers donned fantastical papier-mâché masks — a bright red creature with striped horns, a boar with a floral headdress, an autumn leaf — and marched with gusto in an outdoor masquerade ball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: The ruble crashes, the stock market closes and Russia’s economy staggers under sanctions.
description: The hectic moves were the first signs that Western sanctions were shaking the foundations of Russia’s economy.
content: MOSCOW — The ruble cratered, the stock market froze and the public rushed to withdraw cash on Monday as Western sanctions kicked in and Russia awoke to uncertainty and fear over the rapidly spreading repercussions of President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: David Boggs, Co-Inventor of Ethernet, Dies at 71
description: Thanks to the invention he helped create in the 1970s, people can send email over an office network or visit a website through a coffee shop hot spot.
content: David Boggs, an electrical engineer and computer scientist who helped create Ethernet, the computer networking technology that connects PCs to printers, other devices and the internet in offices and homes, died on Feb. 19 in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marian Bull
title: Three Bedrooms, Two Roommates and a Patch of Dirt
description: A landscape architect wanted his own garden, but that was going to be pricey. So he got a big apartment in Bed-Stuy and looked for flat mates online.
content: Kirk Gordon’s bedroom is ideal for growing plants: light pours in through a pair of windows that look out over his street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, keeping his money tree, jade plant and pencil cactus happy. On the bottom level of a shelving unit, though, he’s brought in some extra help: a set of grow lights casts a bright halo over a row of seedlings and cuttings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Won Ton Soup and Other Essential New York Tastes, Updated at Bonnie’s
description: Cantonese cuisine is deeply woven into the city’s identity. Its old flavors are brought into this century by Calvin Eng’s new restaurant in Brooklyn.
content: When generations of New Yorkers talked about going out for Chinese food, they were almost always talking about Cantonese food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch
title: How a National Movement Toppled Hundreds of Confederate Symbols
description: The murder of George Floyd nearly two years ago sparked critical conversations about systemic racism in America. It also unleashed a movement to remove, relocate and rename monuments and other symbols of the Confederacy.
content: The murder of George Floyd nearly two years ago sparked critical conversations about systemic racism in America. It also unleashed a movement to remove, relocate and rename monuments and other symbols of the Confederacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Lebanon?
description: Can you find Lebanon on a map? What else do you know about this Middle Eastern nation with about seven million people?
content: Can you find Lebanon on a map? What else do you know about this Middle Eastern nation with about seven million people?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: On the Scene: A Molotov Cocktail Supplier
description: If the cruise missile is the weapon that defines the Russian attack on Ukraine, the hand-thrown Molotov cocktail is the emblem of a home-grown resistance.
content: If the cruise missile is the weapon that defines the Russian attack on Ukraine, the hand-thrown Molotov cocktail is the emblem of a home-grown resistance.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A New Generation of Cantonese Food in Brooklyn
description: At Bonnie’s, the chef Calvin Eng applies a modern sensibility to the traditional foods of Guangdong province.
content: At Bonnie’s, the chef Calvin Eng applies a modern sensibility to the traditional foods of Guangdong province.

title: What You Get for $1.5 Million in California
description: A Craftsman house in Upland, a Colonial Revival home in Alameda and a two-bedroom condominium in Beverly Hills.
content: A Craftsman house in Upland, a Colonial Revival home in Alameda and a two-bedroom condominium in Beverly Hills.

title: ‘I Thought I Knew What Bravery Was. And Then I Saw Ukraine.’
description: Readers are moved by the courage of Ukrainians and their president. Also: Judge Jackson’s nomination to the Supreme Court; streaming movies.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Tomorrow is Mardi Gras, which means today is for letting gumbo burble on the stove.
content: Good morning. Mardi Gras is Tuesday, and New Orleans is much on my mind. That’s occasion enough to make gumbo this evening, so it has time to cure in the refrigerator before eating it for dinner tomorrow night. I like Paul Prudhomme’s recipe for that, though you may prefer Leah Chase’s for Creole gumbo (above) or the duck and andouille gumbo they used to serve at Upperline, before the restaurant closed last year. That and a Sazerac? That’s a parade.
source.name: The New York Times
